title: Newton vs. Gibbs: Do We Need Full Dynamics to Simulate Field Evaporation in Atom Probe Tomography?
content: Field evaporation is a fundamental process in atom probe tomography (APT), where an intense electric field created by a high voltage can remove individual atoms or clusters from the surface of a nanoscale needle-shape specimen. The impact positions and sequence of field-evaporated atoms are then recorded by a two-dimensional detector. Together with a time-of-flight mass spectrometer to reveal the chemical identities of the atoms, APT can uniquely resolve both positions and chemical identities of atoms within a bulk material and be used to generate three dimensional reconstructions.
